answers.answer: Hello,higher than usual blood sugar can make you feel tired.To feel better you could try following a low carb diet (by reducing the blood sugar swings your energy should be much better) and also adding in at least 30 minutes of exercise each day.  Though it sounds strange, exercising can actually make you feel better.You should also ask your Dr to check your thyroid levels.  Low thyroid is quite common for people with diabetes.  YOu can also aks for your b vitamin levels to be checked.To know which foods to eat, you can check your blood sugar 2 hours after first bite of food.  If after eating that food / meal your blood sugar is less than 120 (or at worst less than 140) then you know that food / meal is suitable.  IF your blood sugar is higher, then you should adjust the meal next time (typically by reducing the carb content / increasing the healthy fat content (fat slows carbohydrate digestion and means it has less impact on your blood sugars)).Hope this helps.

question: I am in the prediabetes state as far as i know. My last A1c was 5.7. Last summer i started having dizzy spells at work and just feeling so tired and fatigued all the time. I feel like I'm on a roller coaster, up and down a lot. I'm just wondering if anyone else out there feels like this.  I am on Januvia 100 mg once a day. My blood sugar averages 106 in morning and at night around 125.  Anyone with advice on what i can do to help improve my situation from being so tired all the time, would be greatly appreciated.
title: Can having pre-diabetes make you feel tired a lot?
